titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.31 (26 July-2 Aug 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 31. Mercurius Publicus, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence: WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Thur≈øday July 26. to Thur≈øday Augu≈øt 2. 1660.
Whitehal.
div.p: AMong a thou≈øand other Ob≈øervations which His MAJESTIES Travels and Afflictions have taught Him, one is, the Intere≈øt of this I≈øland as to Fi≈øhing, which His MAJESTY comprehends ≈øo perfectly, that as He needs no Council to advi≈øe, ≈øo no Neighbour States or Nation but will finde it; and this is one of tho≈øe infinite Ble≈ø≈øings we enjoy in ≈øuch a Prince (as unle≈øs we be ≈øtark ≈øtaring mad) will render us the mo≈øt happy people under Heaven: For which purpo≈øe hath His MAJES ‚Ä¢ Y now ≈øent a Letter to the Lord Mayor of London, a true Copie whereof we here give you

salute.hi: CHARLS R. Right Tru≈øty and Well beloved, We Greet you well,

body.p:
WHereas Our Royal Father of Ble≈ø≈øed Memory, did in the Year one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred thirty and two, Con≈øtitute and E≈øtabli≈øh a Society of Fi≈øhers, and Declared, That He was re≈øolved by all good occa≈øions favourably to a≈øsi≈øt, and graciou≈øly accept the forwardne≈øs of all tho≈øe that ≈øhould expre≈øs their zeal to His Maje≈øties Service in ≈øo general and publique an Undertaking; It being then Re≈øolved and Concluded by His Maje≈øty, that it was very honourable and nece≈ø≈øary for this Kingdom. Now that the true managing and mo≈øt advantagious pro≈øecution thereof, is by experience di≈øcovered by Philip late Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery and his A≈ø≈øociates, who did cau≈øe ≈øandry Fi≈øhing Ve≈ø≈øels to be provided and built, which employed many Families in making of Nets and other provi≈øions (o ‚Ä¢ e Ve≈ø≈øel employing twenty Families in Work) be≈øides the breeding of Country youths to be made ≈øerviceable Mariners in ≈øhort time, as by the Book called The Royal Herring Bu≈øs Fi≈øhings, pre≈øented unto Us doth plainly appear. And whereas We are informed that the Nation doth abound with great numbers of poor Families and Vagrants, who for wa ‚Ä¢ t of employment are like to peri≈øh, unle≈øs ≈øome ≈øpeedy care be taken for their relief; And that the ≈øeveral Wards and Suburbs of this Our City of London and Hamlets adjacent, are burthened with multitudes of poor peopl ‚Ä¢ , not only which are born in the ≈øaid places, but ≈øuch as come out of ≈øund ‚Ä¢ y Countries to ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ek Relief: For Redre≈øs whereof, We do hereby recommend unto the care of you Our Lord Major of the ≈øaid City, to advi≈øe with each Alderm ‚Ä¢ n, and cau≈øe his Ward-moot Inque≈øt, ‚Ä¢ o give in a particular of all the poor Inhabitants within his Ward what their employment is, and how many are without employment, and pre≈øent the ≈øame to the re≈øt of the Inhabitants to his Ward, with a Copie thereof, and excite them to a free ≈øub≈øcription for Rui≈øing
a Stock to buy Hemp and Cl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ards, to make H ‚Ä¢ rring Fi≈øhing Nets, and Barrel, for the furni≈øhing and fi ‚Ä¢ ting „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Bu≈ø≈øe or Fi≈øhing Ve≈ø≈øel to belong to the ≈øaid Ward, which will give all the Poor and Vagrants employment, the ≈øaid Ward husbanding the ≈øame to their be≈øt advantage. The which We ≈øhall in like manner recommended all the Counties, Cities, and Towns within our Dominions, whereby to make it a National employment for the general gro ‚Ä¢ , and will give all fitting a≈ø≈øi≈øtance unto the Undertakers for their encouragement ‚Ä¢ That ≈øo when Provi≈øions ≈øhall be made ready, and Store-hou≈øes built in commodious places about the River of Thames (where breaches have been made) and the like in the ≈øeveral Ports, Magazines may be ≈øitted with Nets, Cask, Salt, and all things in readine≈øs, The Bu≈ø≈øes may all go forth to Our I≈øland of Sheetland as their Re ‚Ä¢ dezvous to keep together in their Fi≈øhing, accor ‚Ä¢ ing to certain Orders pre≈øcribed in the afore≈øaid Book; and to take that Priviledge of the Fi≈øhing Grounds, which belongs to Us before all Nations what≈øoever. And ≈øo we bid you heartily Farewel.

closer.dateline: Given at our Court at Whitehall this 23. day of July, in the Twelfth Year of Our Reign.
closer.signed: By his Maje≈øties Command. Ed. Nicholas.

opener.salute: To Our Right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved, the Lord Mayor of Our City of London, to be communicated to the Court of Aldermen.

body.p:
We have already given you an account how highly the Nation of Scotland is ≈øatisfied; We ≈øhall now pre≈øent you with the ≈øtate of Affairs in Ireland, wherein it will be very con≈øiderable to look into the affections of the Army, which
we ≈øhal offer you in their own words, as they were pre≈øented in an Addre≈øs to his Maje≈øty, by the Right Honourable the Lord Broghil, viz.

body.head: To the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. The humble Addre≈øs of the Officers of your Maje≈øties Army in and near Dublin in Ireland.
body.p: NOthing can in degrees ≈øo fully proportion our ≈øorrow for the murther of your Royal Father, as our joy for your Re≈øtauration; 'Tis your Maje≈øties Glory, and our ≈øatisfaction, that God hath effected it without blood; the world ≈øees 'tis the day of his power, the people are ≈øo willing in it, none as men but mu≈øt ≈øay 'tis wonderful in our eyes, and none as Chri≈øtians but will ≈øay it is the Lords doings.

Your Maje≈øties Gracious Declaration and Letters to the Parliament, have not onely prevented, but granted our chiefe≈øt de≈øires, and we owe you our mo≈øt ≈øincere and humble acknowledgment, as much for the manner of giving as for the gift; in this we are ≈øafe, in that we are happy.
Your Maje≈øty de≈øires nothing more then to act your clemency, and we de≈øire nothing more then not to appear unworthy of it.
God hath pre≈øerved you abroad in your per≈øon, and which we know is dearer to you, in your Religion, ≈øignal evidences whereof we have already received, for no other Tree could produce ≈øuch fruit.
All your ≈øubjects virtually are in Parliament, and by Parliament you do graciou≈øly promi≈øe to be advi≈øed, your Maje≈øty could not grant more, nor your People ask more.

And to manife≈øt you will Rule by Example as well as Precept, you decline being your own Judge in your deepe≈øt ‚Ä¢ oncernments: Your Royal Fathers Murtherers could not „Äà‚óä„Äâ a greater favour, nor your Parliament a greater tru≈øt;
neither could your Maje≈øty more ≈øen≈øibly and graciou≈øly let the body of your people know, you e≈øteemed them innocent of that ≈øin then by leaving it to them to puni≈øh.

You do not onely ob≈øerve your Laws your ≈øelf, but you freely pardon all your ≈øubjects that have broken them; To be ju≈øt is what all Kings ought to be, but to be merciful is what „Äà‚óä„Äâ King is; the be≈øt of our former Princes appeared worthy of the Crown, but after they wore it, your Maje≈øty has done ≈øo before, the providence of God having taught you to raign over your ≈øelf, before you raigned over your Kingdoms, out of which you were put by violence, but you are re≈øtored by con≈øent, by which through mercy we now live to ≈øee more then hopes of that which we have ≈øo long thir≈øted after, an happy and full agreement between King and people, towards the ataining whereof, we can truly ≈øay, neither our prayers, nor our indeavours in our re≈øpective ≈øtations have been wanting, nor through the goodne≈øs of God ≈øhall they cea≈øe, till what is ≈øo happily begun be compleated.

Your Maje≈øty ≈øhould have earlier received this Tribute of our Loyalty and affection, but that we ≈øtayed till this time to a≈ø≈øure you which now we pre≈øume to do, that generally the Officers and Souldiers in this your Army, have not onely joyfully proclaimed your Maje≈øties Royal undoubted right to your three Kingdoms, but with their hands have ≈øub≈øcribed the ≈øame; and we are confident, if your ≈øervice require it, would do the like with their bloods again≈øt all oppo≈øets.

We have nothing can Apologize for the confidence of this duty, but that out of the abundance of the heart, the mouth will ≈øpeak, which in all humility we hope will obtain both your Maje≈øties belief, and your pardon for

closer.signed: Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt humble and mo≈øt faithful Subjects and Ser ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ts. Signed by the Lord Bro ‚Ä¢ hil, Sir Charles C ‚Ä¢ ot, and all the Officers in and near Dublin ‚ñ™

div.p: Thus you ≈øee how the Souldiery are inclin ‚Ä¢ d to His Maje≈øti ‚Ä¢ s ≈øervice. Nor is there any doubt to be made of the general con≈øent of the whole Kingdom of Ireland, who have expre≈ø≈øed ≈øo much loy ‚Ä¢ lty to His M ‚Ä¢ je≈øty, and towards whom His Maje≈øty hath ≈øhown ≈øo much c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e and tend „Äà‚óä„Äâ , ‚Ä¢ n declaring the Right honble. L. Roberts to be His Deputy the ‚Ä¢ ; wh ‚Ä¢ ch the Commi≈ø≈øioners of that Nation look upon not only as the highe≈øt point of p ‚Ä¢ udence in His Maje≈øty, but as an e≈øpecial Act of Grace and Favour to that Kingdom, he being a per≈øon ≈øo fi ‚Ä¢ ly qualified both for his Wi≈ødom and Integrity for the management of ≈øo grand an Affair.

On Thur≈øday the 26. in≈øtant, the poor and ≈ømall Inland Corporation of Eye in the County of Suffolk, did by the hands of Thomas Dey and Franc ‚Ä¢ Cheney G ‚Ä¢ nt. M ‚Ä¢ mbers of that ≈øaid Corporation (who with Sir George Revo Knight, and Charls cornwallis E≈øquires, Members of Parliament for that plac ‚Ä¢ , were conducted to His Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øty by Sir Frederick Cornwallis Knight and Baronet, Trea≈øurer of His Maje≈øties hou≈øhold) pre≈øent His Maje≈øty with one hundred pounds in Gold. Though this ≈ø ‚Ä¢ em in it ≈øelf but ≈ømal ‚Ä¢ , yet if we look upon the place, we may ju≈øtly judge their Loyalty to be great, and if we con≈øider the ≈øum, with the abilities of the Inhabitants, littl ‚Ä¢ , if at all inferiour to the large≈øt Pre≈øents. His Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to accept it, gave them thanks, and a≈ø≈øured them of his favour to their Corporation.

Th ‚Ä¢ day the Lord Edward Montague, who commanded the Fleet when they received His Maje≈øty and His two Royal Brothers, being for this and other eminent ≈øervices created by His Maje≈øty Earl of Sandwich, Vi≈øcount Hinchinbrook, and Lord B ‚Ä¢ ron of St. Needs, took his place in the Hou≈øe of Peers.

To the≈øe we ≈øha ‚Ä¢ l add ≈øome other Ti ‚Ä¢ les of Honour and Offices which His Maje≈øty hath likewi≈øe conferred on this honourable Per≈øon; and then we mu≈øt tell y ‚Ä¢ u, that be≈øides his Command at Sea under his Highne≈øs he Duke or York, L ‚Ä¢ rd High Admiral, that he is K ‚Ä¢ ight of the mo≈øt Noble Order of the Gar ‚Ä¢ er, M ‚Ä¢ ≈øter of His Maje≈øties great W ‚Ä¢ rdrobe, one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners of His Maje≈øties Trea≈øury, and one of His Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable Privie Council.

Here give us leave to acquaint you That his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to confer the honour of Knighthood on William Tredenham a M ‚Ä¢ mber of Parliament, for St. Mawes in Cornwel, as likewi≈øe to grant the favour of his hand to Major Iohn Blackmore, who was introduced to his Maje≈øty by his Excellency.

On Fryday his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to go to the Hou≈øe of Peers, and to make a gracious Speech for the ≈øpeedy pa≈ø≈øing of the Bill of Indempnity and Oblivion, wherein his Maje≈øty acquainted them how at his fir≈øt coming to them, he did both by Him≈øelf, and the Chancellor, recommend to them and the Hou≈øe of Commons, the ≈øpeedy di≈øpatch of that Act, how ≈øince by a particular Me≈ø≈øage he p ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øed the Hou≈øe of Commons to ha≈øten that work, and did by Proclamation publi≈øh to the whole Kingdom, with what impatience he expected that Act ≈øhould be pre≈øented to him for his A≈ø≈øent, as the mo≈øt rea≈øonable and ≈øolid foundation of Peace and ≈øecurity; how he thought the Hou≈øe of Commons too long about it, and therefore would not have them guilty of the ≈øame dela ‚Ä¢ , thanking God that he had the ≈øame Inten ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ons and Re≈øolutions which he had at Breda and then reading what he then ≈øaid, viz.

And to the end that the F ‚Ä¢ ar of puni≈øhment may not engage any, Con≈øcious to them≈øelves of what is pa≈ø≈øed to a per≈øeverance in Guilt for the future, by oppo≈øing the Quiet and Happine≈øs of their Country in the Restauration both of King Peers and People, to their ‚Ä¢ a≈øt Ancient and Fundamental Rights: We do by the≈øe Pre≈øents Declare, That We do grant a Free and General Pardon, which We are ready upon demand to p ‚Ä¢ ≈øs under Our Great Seal of England, to all Our Subjects, of w ‚Ä¢ at degree
or quality ≈øoever, who, within forty days after the publi≈øhing hereof, ≈øhall lay hold upon th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Our Grace and Favour, and ≈øhall by any Publique Act declare their doing ≈øo; And that they return to the Loyalty and Obedience of good Subjects. (exc ‚Ä¢ pting only ≈øuch p ‚Ä¢ r≈øons as ≈øhall hereafter be excepted by Parliament.) Tho≈øe onely ex ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pted, let all Our loving Subjects, how faulty ≈øoever rely upon the Word of a King, Solemnly given by this pre≈øent Declaration That no Crime what≈øoever committed again≈øt Us or Our Royal Father, before the Publication of this, ≈øhall ever ri≈øe in judgement, or be brought in Que≈øtion again≈øt any of them, to the l ‚Ä¢ a≈øt endammagement of them, either in their ‚Ä¢ ives: Liberties or E≈øtates, or (as far forth as lies in Our Power) ≈øo much as to the Prejudice of their Reputations, by any Repr ‚Ä¢ ach or term of Di≈øtinction from the re≈øt of Our be≈øt Subjects. We d ‚Ä¢ ≈øiring and Ordaining, that henceforward all Notes of Di≈øcord, S ‚Ä¢ paration and Difference of Parties be utterly Aboli≈øhed among all Our Subj ‚Ä¢ cts, whom We invite and Conjure to a perfect Union among them≈øelves under Our Prot ‚Ä¢ ction, for the Re≈øettlement ‚Ä¢ f Our Ju≈øt Rights, and theirs, in a Free Parliament; By which upon the Word of a King, We will be advi≈øed.

His Maje≈øty then added, That if they did not then joyn with him in extingui≈øhing the ‚Ä¢ ear which keeps the hearts of men awake and apprehen≈øive of ≈øafety and ≈øecurity, they would keep him from performing his Promi≈øe. His Maje≈øty thank'd them for their ju≈øtice to tho≈øe that had been the imm ‚Ä¢ diate Murtherers of his Father, and a≈ø≈øured them he never thought excepting any other. Many other Arguments his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to make u≈øe of, de≈øiring and co ‚Ä¢ juring them again and again, that laying al ‚Ä¢ particular Animo≈øities a≈øide, they would pa≈øs that Act without any other exceptions, then of tho≈øe who were immediately guilty of the Murther of his Father.

On Saturday the 28. The truly Honourable, and perfect Pattern of Loyalty, Marquis of Ormond, being created and ≈øummoned by Writ from his Maje≈øty, as Earl of Brecknock, took his place in the H ‚Ä¢ u≈øe of Peers.
H ‚Ä¢ ving i ‚Ä¢ our former ≈øh ‚Ä¢ et acquainted you with the times and places of the Circuits we ≈øhall now give you the names of the Judges.
Judges for the We≈øt Circuit, are Ju≈øtice Foster and Ju≈øtice Tyrrill, of the Common Pleas.
The home Circuit, Lord Chief Baron and Serjean Waller.
Oxford Circuit, are Ju≈øtice Mallet of the Kings Bench, and Baron Turner.
N ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h Circuit, are Ju≈øtice Twi≈øden of the Kings Bench, and Serjeant Barnard.
Northampton Circuit, are Baron Atkins and Serjeant Earle.
Norfolk Circui ‚Ä¢ , are Ju≈øtice Hyde of the Common Pleas, and Serjeant Archer.

The ≈øame day his Sacred Maje≈øty went to the Hou≈øe of Peers, and gave his Royal A≈ø≈øent to the≈ø ‚Ä¢ Acts following viz. An Act for Continuing the Exci≈øe. An Act for Tonnage and Poundage; An Act for Commi≈øsioners of Sewers.

div.head: El≈øeneur July 14.
div.p:
We are ≈øtill very bu≈øie here (almo≈øt day and night) to tran≈øport the Swedi≈øh Forces over into Schonen, and the endeavours of the Hollands Admiral de Ruyter, is much to be
commended, for a≈ø≈øi≈øting and helping the tran≈øportation, which if it had not been for his Fleet, might po≈ø≈øibly have been retarded yet a good while. La≈øt Saturday ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels with Foot ≈øouldiers arrived here from Copenhagen, which are to be the Garri≈øon of Cronenburg Ca≈øtle, but they are not yet landed, till the Ca≈øtle be delivered up by the Swedes, which is conceived will be done within a few days. Letters from Copenhagen intimate, that the Engli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadours will be here on Monday next, to take ≈øhipping for England.

div.head: Hamburgh, Iuly 24.
div.p: The Armies hereabouts lye ≈øtill in their Quarters, and the report is, that they will ≈øuddenly break up, but as yet there but ≈ømall appearance of it. Count Koning≈ømarck hath di≈øbanded ≈øeveral Officers in the Dukedom of Bremen, and reduceth the Regiments. Cronenburg is not yet delivered to the Danes. The Hollands Admiral de Ruyter is bu≈øie in tran≈øporting the Swedi≈øh Forces over into Fuhnen. The Dantzick Po≈øt was robbed ≈øix leagues off this place, which cau≈øeth that no Letters are come this day.

div.head: Hague, Iuly 31.
div.p: The bu≈øine≈øs at Utrecht is not yet appea≈øed, ≈øo as it was thought, but is grown higher then formerly, in≈øomuch as there hath been this week three companies more commanded thither to re-inforce the former thither ≈øent; and it is to be fear'd much trouble may en≈øue upon this difference m ‚Ä¢ de between the Mini≈øters and the Magi≈øtrates there, the former whereof having begun the trouble, 'tis thought may ≈øeverely ≈ømart for it. Mijn Heer Mycope who hath been long detained a Pri≈øoner concerning Accompts belonging to the States, hath now his ≈øentence for to pay 15000 gild. fine, defray all charges of Impri≈øonment, and to an≈øwer at the Law all Suits that ≈øhall be brought again≈øt him by any per≈øon he hath wronged, M. Bo≈øhuy≈øen and two more guilty of the ≈øame fact, have all their goods and e≈øtates confi≈øcated, and their per≈øons for ever bani≈øhed.

div.head: Adverti≈øement of a Book newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p: ‚òû Divine Efficacy without Humane Power. Opened in a Sermon Preached at St. Margarets Church in VVe≈øtmin≈øter, before the Right Honorable the Hou≈øe of Commons, June 2. 1660. Being the day of ≈øolemn Thank giving for the Happy Return of the Kings Maje≈øty. By Edward Reynolds D. D. and Chaplai ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ ordinary to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. Sold by George Thoma≈øon at the Ro≈øe and Crown in St. Pauls Church-yard.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: ALL Deputy Po≈øtma≈øters and Officers, that hold them≈øelves concerned in the Settlement of the Po≈øts, in the ≈øeveral Stages of Plymouth road and Bri≈øtol road, are de≈øired to take notice, that an Agent is appointed by the Ma≈øter of his Maje≈øties Po≈øt-Office who begins his journey towards Plymouth upon Thur≈øday the Second of Augu≈øt, to ≈øettle all the Po≈øts in the ≈øeveral Stages upon that road, who returns by B ‚Ä¢ i≈øtol, to ≈øettle all the Posts al≈øo upon that roade.

GEntlemen, You are de≈øired to take notice, That Mr. Theophilus Buckworth who for ≈øome years pa≈øt permitted, and gave directions to his Brother Mr. Edmond Buckworth, to make and expo≈øe to ≈øale for the publick good, tho≈øe ≈øo famous Lozanges or Pectorals approved for the cure of Con≈øumptions, Coughs, Catarchs, A≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m ‚Ä¢ 's, Hoar≈øne≈øs, Strongne≈øs of Boc ‚Ä¢ th, Coins in general, D ‚Ä¢ ≈øea≈øes incident to the Lungs, and a ≈øoveraign An ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ e again≈øt the Plague, and all other contagious Di≈øea≈øes, and ob≈øtructions of the Stomach. doth now him≈øelf (bei ‚Ä¢ g the Author and fir≈øt compounder of them) make them at his Hou≈øe on Mile-end Green. And for more conveniency of the people, con≈øtantly leaveth them ≈øealed up with his Coat of Arms on the Papers with Mr. Richard ‚Ä¢ owndes (as formerly) at the ≈øign of the White Lion „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Little North door of Pauls Church, Mr. Henry
‚Ä¢ ei ‚Ä¢ e over again≈øt Dun≈øta ‚Ä¢ s Church in Fleet≈øtreet, M ‚Ä¢ . William Milward at We ‚Ä¢ minste ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ H ‚Ä¢ ll Gat ‚Ä¢ , Mr. John Pla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
at Furni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ als-Inn Gate in Holborn, and Mr. Robert Horn at the Turks head near the entrance of the Royal Exc ‚Ä¢ ange Book≈øellers, and no others.

p.hi: This is publi≈øhed to prevent the d ‚Ä¢ ≈øigns of divers pretenders who counterfeit the ≈øaid Lozenges to the di≈øparagement of the ≈øaid Gentleman, and great abu≈øe the people.

div.p:
ON Wedne≈øday the 2 ‚Ä¢ of July was ≈øtolen out of Peekham f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ld, thr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Miles off London, a Sorr ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ teen hand ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ high, having two Wall eyes, Bald fac'd, four white feet, much white about him, having „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øides ga ‚Ä¢ len with a Pack-≈øaddle, being a Bakers hor≈øe. If any per≈øon can bring tidings to Mr Bellamy at the Plying hor≈øe in
‚Ä¢ hames-≈øtreet, near the Bride Foot, they ≈øhall be well rewarded for their pai ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

His Sacred Maje≈øty gave his Royal a≈ø≈øent to the≈øe Acts following: The Act for Tonnage and Poundage; The Act for continuing the Exci≈øe till the 20. of Augu≈øt 1660. An Act for the pre≈øent nominating of the Commi≈øsioners of Sewers; and An Act for the re≈øtoring James Marque≈øs of Ormond all his Honors, Mannors, Lands and Tenements in Ireland, whereof he was in po≈øse≈øsion on the 23. day of October 1641. or at any time ≈øince.

Of the≈øe we ≈øhall give you ≈øome account, referring tho≈øe that are de≈øirous of farther ≈øatisfaction, to the Acts printed at large by his Maje≈øties Printers. In the fir≈øt there is granted to his Maje≈øty, of every Ton of French wine brought into the Port of London by his Maje≈øties natural born ≈øubjects by way of merchandi≈øe, 4 l. 10 s. and by ≈øtrangers 6 l. If brought to any other Port, by natural born ≈øubjects 3 l. by ≈øtrangers 4 l. 10 s. Of every But or Pipe of wines of the growth of Levant, Spain or Portugal, brought into the Port of London by his Maje≈øties natural born ≈øubjects, 2 l. 5 s. by ≈øtrangers 3 l. if brought into any other Port, by a natural born ≈øubject 1 l. 10 s. by ≈øtrangers 2 l. 5 s. Of every Acom of wine of the growth of Germany, brought into his Maje≈øties Realm and Dominions by natural born ≈øubjects 20 s. by ≈øtrangers 25 s. There is al≈øo granted another Sub≈øidy of Poundage, viz. of all goods exported or imported by way of merchandi≈øe by any natural born ≈øubject Denizen and Alien, of every 20 s. valued according to the Book of Rates ‚Ä¢ 2 d. and of every 20 s. value of any native commodity or manufacture wrought of native commodity, carried out by any Merchant alien, 12 d. over above the 12 d. afore≈øaid, excepting Old Draperies, Wines limited to pay Tonage, &c. in the Books of Rates Cu≈øtom-free.

There is likewi≈øe granted a further Sub≈øidy to continue from the 24. of June inclu≈øively during his Maje≈øties life, for every ≈øhort Woolen cloth not above 28 yards long, and 64 l. weight, exported by any natural born ≈øubject, of 3 s. 4 d. and of every Cloth of greater length and weight proportionably, and of every ≈øhort Cloth of le≈ø≈øer length
and weight, accounting ≈øo much to a ≈øhort Cloth according to the Book of Rates 3 s. 4 d. if exported by ≈øtrangers, 6 s. 8 d.

It is further enacted, That if any goods be put in a ve≈ø≈øel to be exported, or un≈øhipp'd to be laid on land, Duties being unpaid, and no agreement for them in the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, the goods ≈øhall be forfeited one moye ‚Ä¢ ie to his Maje≈øty, the other to him that ≈øei≈øeth or ≈øueth for them.

It is further enacted, That if the goods of any Merchant born Denizen after the ≈øaid 24. of June, ≈øhall be taken by Pyrates or peri≈øhed at ≈øea, during his Maje≈øties life, the duties and Sub≈øidies being formerly paid, and due proof be made thereof, the ≈øame Merchant, his executors or admini≈øtrators may ≈øhip ≈øo much goods as were lo≈øt, without paying any thing for the ≈øame. And that every Merchant Denizen that ≈øhall ≈øhip any goods in a Carrack or Gally, ≈øhall pay as an Alien.

Provided notwith≈øtanding, that all Herrings and Sea-fi≈øh taken on the ≈øea by his Maje≈øties ≈øubjects, may be tran≈øported out of this Realm in ve≈ø≈øels of his, Maje≈øties ≈øubjects, without payment of Cu≈øtom, Sub≈øidy or Poundage, during his Maje≈øties life.

It is further enacted, that the Rates intended in this Act are tho≈øe mentioned in a booke entituled, The Rates of Merchandi≈øe, ≈øub≈øcribed with the hand of Sir Harbottle Grim≈øton Baronet, which booke is to remaine during His Maje≈øties life.

It is further enacted, that where the goods amount to the value of 5 l. or more, no other fees ≈øhall be received than ≈øuch as were taken in the fourth year of the late King James, without further Authority of Parliament.

Provided that no per≈øon who betwixt the 24 of June and the 24 of July 1660. hath received or paid any duties or Cu≈øtomes according to the Rates u≈øed in April 1660. ≈øhall be mole≈øted for ≈øuch receipt or payment.
And it is declared that no per≈øon who hath ≈øhipped any goods in the ≈øame time, ≈øhall be lyable to the payment of any other duties than ≈øuch as were u≈øed in April 1660.

It is likewi≈øe enacted, that it may be lawfull to tran≈øport I≈øhn, Armor, Bandileers, Bridle-Bits, Halbert-Heads and harpes, Muskets, Carbines, Fowling-pieces, Pi≈øtols, Pike
‚Ä¢ eads, Sword or Rapier Blades, Saddles, Snaffles, Stirrops, Calveskins dre≈ø≈øed or undre≈ø≈øed, Geldings, Oxen, Sheepskins dre≈ø≈øed without the Wool, and all Manufactures made of Leather, as al≈øo Gunpowder, when the price doth not exceed 5 l. the Barrel, Wheat when at 40 s. the quarter, Rye, Beans and Pea≈øe at 24 s. the quarter, Barley and Mault at 20 s. the quarter, Oates at 10 s. the Quarter, Beefe at 5 l. a B ‚Ä¢ rrel, Porke at 6 l. 10 s. a Barrel, Bacon at 6 d. a pound, Butter at 4 l. 10 s. the Barrel, Chee≈øe at 1 l. 10 s. the hundred, Candles at 5 s. a dozen pound at the Ports when they are laden, any law to the contrary notwith≈øtanding.
Provided that it be free for his Maje≈øty notwith≈øtanding this Act, to prohibit at any time the tran≈øporting of Gunpowder, or any Armes or Ammunition.

It is further enacted, that be≈øides the former Rates there ≈øhall be paid to his Maje≈øty, out of every Tun of Wine of the growth of France, Germany, Portugal, or Mardera, 3 l. of other Wine 4 l, within 9 moneths after the importing for which ≈øecurity ≈øhall be given; but if the ≈øame Wines ≈øhall be exported within 12 moneths, the ≈øecurity he ≈øhall be di≈øcharg'd or if he hath paid money he ≈øhall be allowed at 10 per Cent for a year.
It is farther enacted, that after the 24 of July all Wines ≈øhall be di≈øcharged from the Impo≈øition of Exci≈øe.
It is further provided that the prize Wines ought not to pay or be charged with any Cu≈øtome, Sub≈øidy &c.

In the Act for continuing the Exci≈øe, the Impo≈øition of Exci≈øe is continued to be collected & paid, as al≈øo arrears unpardoned to the Commi≈ø≈øioners that now Collect the ≈øame from the 24 of June inclu≈øively 1660. to the 24 of Augu≈øt the ≈øame year; provided all ≈øorts of Oyles, Wines, &c. imported after the 24 of July 1661 be di≈øcharged from that duty.

In the Act for Commi≈øsioners of Sewers, It is enacted, that Commi≈ø≈øions of Sewers ≈øhall and may be directed at any time
before the 23 of October next en≈øuing, not after, according to the manner and forme expre≈ø≈øed in the Statute of the 23 of King Henry the 8, as the Lord Chancellor Lord ComCommi≈ø≈øioner of the Trea≈øury, the Chancellor of the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, Lord Cheif Baron of the Exchequer and the Ju≈øtices of either Bench or any 3 of them wket ‚Ä¢ of the Lord Chancellor. to be one ≈øhall appoint and that they ≈øhall have full power to execute as any Commi≈ø≈øioners of Sewers ot any time before.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: REader, pray take notice, that in His Maje≈øties Proclamation lately ≈øet forth for dayes of holding the A≈øsi≈øes in the ≈øeveral Counties of this Kingdom, there is a great mi≈øtake for the day of holding the A≈øsi≈øes for the County of Cornwal, which is there ≈øaid to be Wedne≈øday the Fifteenth day of September, whereas it ≈øhould have been Wedne≈øday the Nineteenth day of September; of which all per≈øons may take notice.

THere was lo≈øt between Bi≈øhop≈ø gate≈øtreet and Grayes-Inn, a black box, ≈øomwhat ≈øquare, wherein there were Parchments, written in Latine, Sealed. If any one can give notice thereof to Mr. Skelion a Book≈øeller in Duck-lane, at the ≈øign of the hand and bible, he ≈øhall be well rewarded.

If any per≈øon have found a ≈ømall Almanack of Gold ≈ømiths, bound in Blew Leather, with gilt Leaves and Cla≈øpes, lo≈øt either in Whitehal or We≈øtmin≈øter, upon Saturday the twenty eighth of this Mouth; they are de≈øired to leave it at Mr. Charles Toveys hou≈øe, an Apothecary at the ≈øign of the Hor≈øhooe near the New-Exchange, and they ≈øhall be rewarded for their pains.

div.head: Paris the 30 of July S. N.
div.p:
Saturday la≈øt the Queen mother was at Ma≈øs in the Church of Notre Dame, from whence ≈øhe came to the Ca≈øtle of Vicennes, and dined there with the King‚ñ™ On Monday the Cardinal was very ill of the Gout and Gravel, but by vertue of ≈øome remedy which was given
him, he vo ‚Ä¢ ded two ≈øtones, ≈øince which he hath been pretty well. The King vi≈øits him every day with great care, and ≈øo doth the Queen Mother; Prayers are made in all Churches for his recovery, which now only is expected, to appoint the day for the Queens entrance, for which preparations are ≈øtill made‚ñ™ and with much indu≈øtry continued. To make the Shew the more ≈øplendid, the Citizens are daily a≈ø≈øembled in all the parts of this Town‚ñ™ to exerci≈øe and train them up in Arms.

Some days ≈øince the Abbot Fantoni, Envoy Extraordinary from Poland, had audience with the King, whom, in his Ma≈øters name, he gave thanks for tho≈øe good offices his Amba≈ø≈øadors had done concerning the peace with Sweden and Poland, and afterwards Complemented his Maje≈øty touching his Marriage: He had likewi≈øe audience given him by the Queen Mother, the young Queen, the Duke of Anjon, and Cardinal Mazarini, with whom, it is ≈øaid‚ñ™ he had al≈øo a conference touching the pre≈øent War with the Mu≈øcovites.

div.head: From the Ca≈øtle of Vicennes of the ≈øame date.
div.p: The King and Queen are daily here, expecting the day of their entrance at Paris, and the recovery of the C ‚Ä¢ rd ‚Ä¢ nal, for who≈øe pre≈øent indi≈øpo≈øition the whole Court ≈øeemeth to be troubled. The young Queen having a minde to divert her ≈øelf, and to ≈øee the fa≈øhion of Paris, went incognito in Madamo ‚Ä¢ ≈øelle d'Orlea ‚Ä¢ her Coach o ‚Ä¢ Munday la≈øt, towards this City; but the noi≈øe of her coming being bruited all over the Town, the people ran to meet th ‚Ä¢ coach with ≈øuch a multitude, that her Maje≈øty was forced to return back. And becau≈øe ≈øhe had ≈øtill a de≈øire of ≈øeeing Paris, ≈øhe went thither ye≈øterday unknown, accompanied by Mon≈øieur the Duke of A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ion where by the way ≈øhe ≈øaw the Queen Mother at Val de grace, their Maje≈øties went together to the Louvre, and thence they vi≈øited the Cardinal, and ≈øo returned to Vicennes. A Courrier is lately di≈øpatched hence ‚Ä¢ or Spai ‚Ä¢ , to carry the news of ≈øome evident marks taken notice of, that the Queen is with childe.

div.head: Whitehall.
div.p: On Monday la≈øt his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to confer the honor of Knighthood on a young Swedi≈øh Nobleman, Baron Conrad Gyllen≈øtierna.

We have no ‚Ä¢ of late made any mention of Millitary Affa ‚Ä¢ rs, which being at the pre≈øent a matter of great importrnce as to the ≈øafety of the Kingdom
and pre≈øervation of the quiet of the people, we ≈øhall now be ≈øomwhat the more large in giving you an account of the Officers of the Army lately ≈øetled in command. And fir≈øt we ≈øhall begin to give you a Li≈øt of tho≈øe not formerly mentioned in the Lord Vi≈øcount Mordant his Regiment, viz.

Hartigill Broon Capt. Tho: Higgins Capt. Francis Arundel Lieut. Phil. Er ‚Ä¢
En≈øign. Tho Pride Capt. James Smith Lieut: Nath. Hari≈øon Capt. James Gerrard Lieut: Rich. Gwyn Capt. _____
Rowlen≈øon Lieut: Antho: Ha≈øtings En≈øign.

Next we ≈øhall acquaint you with ≈øome little alteration in Col. Tho. Reads Regiment, where Peter Pike, late Capt. Li ‚Ä¢ utenant, hath the Company that was Capt: Belohams, who is removed from that command, John Curtice Capt. Lieut. Marris Brown En≈ø ‚Ä¢ . to Capt. Pike in the place of Robert Read. Francis Everard Lieutenant to Capt. George Everard, William Jones En≈øign‚ñ™ We ≈øhall now ≈øhow you how the Regiment of Hor≈øe that was ∆≤nton Crokes, is di≈øpo≈øed of viz. Dan Oneale of his Maje≈øties Bedchamber, Colonel of the Regiment, William Ba≈ø≈øet Son of Sir Richard Ba≈ø≈øet Governor of Cardiffe Ca≈øtle, Capt. Lieut. Sir John Stevens Major‚ñ™ Lord Mandevil, elde≈øt Son of the Earl of Manche≈øter, Lord Chamberlain of his Maje≈øties hou≈øhold, Captain of the Tro ‚Ä¢ p l ‚Ä¢ te Capt. Whethams, Lord Wind≈øor Captain, Nicholas Armerer, Capt. one of his Maje≈øties E≈øquires, commands the Troop late Capt. Ga≈øcoignes. Bartue, Second Son of the Earl of Lind≈øey, Captain of that which was Col. ∆≤pcotts Troop. That Regiment that was Col. Tho: Sheffeilds, is now commanded by the Right Honorable Lord O≈ø≈øerie, elde≈øt Son of the Marquis of Ormond, and Tho: Shieffeild is his Lieutenant Colonel.
Having thus far ≈øhewed you the ≈øettlement of the Army, now take an account of ≈øome Garri≈øons, where we ≈øhall fir≈øt begin with
Earl of Portland Governor of the I≈øle of Wight, and all the Garri≈øons and Ports therein.
Humphrey Turney Captain of Comes Ca≈øtle.
Barnaby Burleigh (brother to that valiant Burleigh that was murthered in the I≈øle of Wight) Governor of Yarmouth in the I≈øle of Wight.
William Lord Sandys Governor of Portland, Weymouth' and Sandfoot Ca≈øtle.
With the≈øe we will take in George Rawleigh Captain-Lieutenant to the Right honorable the Earl of S. Albans in the I≈øland of Jer≈ø ‚Ä¢ y.

Though the≈øe per≈øons and others entru≈øted with Commands in the Army, are of greater fidelity then to be ≈øu≈øpected in the lea≈øt of di≈øloyalty, yet too much care cannot be taken for the ≈øafety and ≈øecurity of his Maje≈øties Kingdoms; and
to this purpo≈øe, ≈øeveral Commi≈ø≈øions are granted under the Great Seal of England, to per≈øons of known integrity and loyalty, to admini≈øter the oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy to all the Officers and Soldiers, particularly to Buller, a Member of this pre≈øent Parliament, and Major of his Highne≈øs the Duke of York's Regiment, to ≈øee that duty performed by the Officers and Soldiers of the ≈øaid Regiment; as al≈øo another Commi≈ø≈øion to Jeremiah Smith, to ≈øee the ≈øame done in Sir John Cloberies Regiment, of which he is Major.

Commi≈ø≈øions under the Great Seal are likewi≈øe i≈ø≈øued out to the ≈øeveral Mu≈øter-ma≈øters in Ireland, to admini≈øter the ≈øaid Oath of Supremacy and Allegiance to all the Officers and Soldiers within the Precinct of their Mu≈øters.
Care is likewi≈øe taken for ≈øetling the Militia in ≈øuch hands as may be mo≈øt ≈øerviceable to his Maje≈øty, and ≈øatisfactory to all that wi≈øh the peace of the Nation.

Letters from Edenbrough of the 26 July, inform us that the Engli≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners there, have ≈øent up ≈øuch Soldiers as were in the Ho≈øpital at Edenbrough, to London, to be further provided for: as likewi≈øe, that they have relea≈øed ≈øeveral Pri≈øoners, ≈øome that were driven in by a ≈øtorm at Kelkowbery, and there taken, belonging to Cap. Patrick Taylor, ‚Ä¢ n the ≈øhip called the St. A ‚Ä¢ n of St. Seba≈øtian, as al≈øo above 20 others that were taken by his Maje≈øties Frig ‚Ä¢ t called the Greyhound. They give us no other account of the La ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d Warri≈øton, than that they have yet no Intelligence of him, though a hundred pound Sterling is a≈ø≈øured to any one that ≈øhall bring him.
For the Legal di≈øpatch of Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters, Dr. Chawworth was by the Dean and Chapter of Canterbury, elected Vicar-General above a Fortnight ≈øince‚ñ™
London, Printed by John Macock and Tho: Newcomb ‚ñ™ 1660.
